area_name: Pumping Station; Wall of Doom, Gomar, Glace Eclatante

content.description:
A typical Orient Bay ice flow, except that it faces north and is across the valley from most of the climbs in the area. You've probably seen it as you drove round the bend near the Ice Palace. High up on the bluff, tucked in it's own little alcove. If you do decide to brave the approach (it's not the bad!) you won't be disappointed. There are multiple lines to the top, pick whichever one looks good to you and swing 'em hard.

Park as for Glace Eclatante or April Ice and either cross the river or find your way around to a snowmobile trail. Keep looking left and up for when to cut into the woods. Plenty of ice up there to accommodate for multiple parties.
Screws for the lead, belay from trees, soak in the view of the sun glinting off of the Ice Palace Routes and Glace across the way. Rap the route and slide down the hill.

climbs.name: Bananarama
climbs.fa: Shaun Parent, David Pagel, Joanne Murphy.  1984

content.description:
Pitch 1. A steep step of ice climbs up into a low-angle gully that steepens and widens at top. Anchor webbing at a tree on the left side of the top, visible from the start of the climb. Pitch 2. Climb to the tree that reveals the secret meaning of the climb. (Didn't climb second pitch due to time, please add info in a comment, I'll add here) Left-most climb in the McKirdy Lake area.
We hiked in by some power lines part of the way, bushwhacked last part. Screws. Bring as many as you think you'll need for a climb of this difficulty/length.
There may be trees to sling on the second pitch.
Two-rope rappel to get down pitch 1.

This is a huge vertical sheet with an ice cave that forms near the middle. There are multiple lines to suit anyone. This route is in the sun much of the day and can get rotten in the late season.

This is the first major chunk of ice that you come across on Hwy 11 from Nipigon.
Screws. Pro is easy to get.

climbs.name: Gomar Falls
climbs.fa: Shaun Parent, Paul Dedi, Joanne Murphy. 1982

content.description:
The fattest piece of ice in Orient Bay. Pretty straight forward once you reach the base. Pick your line and shoot. There are rap stations all along the edges and at least one at the very top.

SNOWSHOES ARE REQUIRED! Approach will take 30 min to 1 hr depending on if you are breaking trail. To get to this route park at the pump station, cross the road and follow the power cuts straight into the woods. You will be following the cliff line for a while and a flagged trail will appear. The trail will lead you onto a creek (watch it I almost fell through). At this point Gomar will be standing above you and will get bigger and bigger the closer you get. To see this route from the road, pass the pump station, look back to your right. It is on the north facing cliff and is impossible to miss.
Screws

climbs.name: Photomaniac
climbs.fa: Shaun Parent, A.V. Schaik, H. Perkins. 1985

content.description: A nice second pitch on the right side of the bowl above White Plague. Most of this route gets slightly less sun than the rest of the routes in the bowl, making it a good choice in warm and sunny conditions. On the right side of the bowl above White Plague. Screws

climbs.name: White Plague
climbs.fa: Shaun Parent, B. Bingeman, Ed Iwasa.  1984

content.description:
Climb the falls immediately left of Gomar Falls. The route can reportedly vary from WI2-WI3 with easier conditions being found later in the season. I climbed it in mid-February 2017 (a fat year) at WI2. This route is used as the first pitch access to a higher bowl where a number of second pitches can be chosen from including from L-to-R: China CrisisPhotomaniac Immediately to the left of Gomar Falls. Follow directions given there:

Gomar Falls Approach Screws

content.description: Routes in this area lie between the South End and the Ice Palace
